content: The maximum string length of 100 in the stub generator seems to be too low for ide test cases 6-9.

Do you have to do something special to get the codingame console output to display the fruit emoji? I've tried a lot of different ways to debug print the unicode input, and echoing the puzzle input always shows: "$12 = ????????"

If the only way to debug the unicode input is to print the encoded bytes in hex, is there a way to hint that in the puzzle description? Not being able to debug the different characters feels like the sort of problem that will defeat novice programmers.

The php stub  stream_get_line(STDIN, 100 + 1, "\n"); trims the last line of input by the number of lines.
so use rtrim(fgets(STDIN)); or stream_get_contents and split as appropriate.   The byte sequence for the emoji's is 240,159,xxx,xxx .  There's some other simple trickery if the emoji isn't defined, it could be just an ascii code if it's not defined with a value even if prefixed with 240,159

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, I enjoyed learning about handling multibyte characters.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's very original and teaches people something no other puzzle does: handling multi-byte characters. Tried it in Java and everything works great. The tests are really nice.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle, the tricky part is to find how to handle the emoji properly, after that it's easy, statement is clear. Good tests/validators like always.

You'd want to state explicitly how emojis are encoded.
Is it utf-8? Is it utf-32? Don't make your players to figure out by trial.

Goal section
* Please fix the typo in the last sentence üòâ.

Output section
* Please add "(thousands separator)" for clarity.

Constraints section
* Suggest to move it to Goal section (it's rather an "un-constraint" really).

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement üòÜ.

Thanks.

Thanks.  I've now made 75% of your suggested-changes.:)

How bad would it be if I just left the "un-constraint" in the constraint section?

I really like how beautifully streamlined my "Goals" section is, and don't want to clutter it with that insignificant detail.
Thanks.  I added that in the Constraints section.
Thanks !
Thanks!
I guess the garden received is near the max size so the stub fails at the end, that's my best guess.

Thanks for the feedback.
Honestly, I don't really know that much about emojis, so I hesitate to actually personally write that tip.
Here is what I have as a draft.  What do you think??:

<<Hint if needed:>>
One way to debug the unicode input is to print the encoded bytes in hex.

Thanks for the feedback.

I asked 5DN1L's advice (far below on this) and they said:
TBali's comment
* I don't exactly know how the stub generator works with non-ASCII characters, but if 100 is too low (maybe something to do with counting bytes), then just set it to a higher number (Test in CodinGame IDE before finalising the figure).

So I just changed 100 to 500.  Hopefully that solves any issue.  Thanks for the feedback and let me know if any other issues, please
Yeah, that would help! I don't really know that much about emoji either xD
Done :)
@CarlWalsh, I'm curious whether there's any specific reason for you to use the term "encoded bytes"?

I guess more precisely, the "UTC-8 bytes decoded into hex format" (or, maybe I'm not sure what you're asking?) 

A beginning user might not know what way to view a text representative of the string data (a.k.a. the encoding), because printing the actual emoji doesn't work?

And hex encoding of UTF-8 is hard to use, but easier than directly using ASCII encoding.

Yeah, my concern is whether a beginner knows what that term refers to, "What bytes? What's encoded? Does it mean something's encrypted?"

When I do in Python:
print(ord("üçì"))
It gives me 127827.

Similarly in C#:
string emoji = "üçì";
Console.WriteLine(char.ConvertToUtf32(emoji, 0)); // 127827

Hence, I would suggest the following wording with simpler terms:

Currently the console of CodinGame cannot display non-ASCII characters properly. One way to print (debug) the input in the console is to convert the input characters to their character codes and print those codes instead.

Excellent.  I made that change.

I definitely got "ahead of my skis" on this one.
I just treated each emoji as a two character string (just like "it" for example) and manipulated thus.

The debugging is a higher grade level than I had delved into.  Thanks for saving me :)

@CarlWalsh, no problem, and I'm learning as well!

Regarding the "harder" suggestion, maybe use other "non-ASCII" currency symbols and codes (¬£, ¬•, ‚Çπ, ‚Ç¨, KRW, NZD, SGD, etc) and introduce exchange rates üòõ ?

I believe TBali above had the same issue (if I understand correctly).
So please see my see my response above to TBali.

Thank you for the feedback and for playing my puzzle.

That's not insignificant! It's not easy to tell whether the lines are of the same length given that the Unicode and ASCII characters are mixed. Some players may wrongly assume that the lines are of the same length and write a wrong code.

Okay, thanks, I trust your judgement.

I reworded it, and added it to Goals.  How is it all now ?

Thank you. I, for one, made the wrong assumption initially, until I re-read the inputs carefully.

And, an easy way to get rid of that constraint while not "cluttering" the Goal section: just add "of irregular shape" to "garden" instead of showing it as an additional note üòâ

Hey, this got accepted a few days ago and I have three new comments that I don‚Äôt know how to respond to ‚Ä¶. so question for you:
(1) thoughts on those new comments
(2) what has to happen so my puzzle gets a ‚Äúdiscussion‚Äù tab like other puzzles, so people aren‚Äôt commentating in this ‚Äúbehind the scenes area‚Äù?

I'll answer your question 2 first. I'll need some time to digest the comments in relation to question 1.

(a) There were a few times when the forum bot CommunityBot failed to automatically create a new discussion *thread* and I manually created one for each of them without bothering CG staff. So, if you want, you may copy the format from the other CommunityBot posts and start a new discussion thread yourself, or I can do it for you if you want to.

(b) I've already got an incomplete list of puzzles where the discussion *tab* is missing from the puzzle pages. (It's an evergrowing list as well because I keep updating it when I become aware of a new puzzle which exhibits that issue.) I would have requested CG staff to fix that, but the new guy who replaced the ex-Community Manager now *never* replies to my PMs on Discord regarding the requests I made almost half a year ago (and he still replied to me a few times back then), and I won't raise any new requests until the earlier ones have been addressed. So, you may either raise a bug for your particular puzzle in the bug channel on Discord, or wait for me to raise a request to fix all the affected puzzles (*if* that happens, that is)...

(c) I suspect that non-ASCII characters in the title may have caused the issue for CommunityBot. I've just found that the same thing happened to the puzzle "üÉè FreeCell üÉè": https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/community-puzzle-freecell/188909

TBali's comment
* I don't exactly know how the stub generator works with non-ASCII characters, but if 100 is too low (maybe something to do with counting bytes), then just set it to a higher number (Test in CodinGame IDE before finalising the figure).

CarlWalsh's comment
* Yeah, we both know that the console does not display non-ASCII characters properly. I think adding a hint in the statement as per CarlWalsh's comment is the way to address the issue for now.

PatrickMcGinnisII's comment
* Seems to be the same issue raised by TBali? If you aren't sure, you may ask him to clarify his question.

You may also want to keep other non-ASCII puzzles private first for the time being if necessary.

Thanks for all your time on this !!!

What do you think about me adding the following phrase at the end of the Goals Section?  (Honestly I am not educated enough to know if this is good or not)

<<Hint if needed:>> 
One way to debug the unicode input is to print the encoded bytes in hex.

When I do in Python:
print(ord("üçì"))
It gives me 127827.

Similarly in C#:
string emoji = "üçì";
Console.WriteLine(char.ConvertToUtf32(emoji, 0)); // 127827

The result matches the info here:
https://www.codetable.net/decimal/127827

Hence, I would suggest a more general hint and a bit of explanation:

Currently the console of CodinGame cannot display non-ASCII characters properly. One way to print (debug) the input in the console is to convert the input characters to their character codes and print those codes instead.
And oh, I'm not *that* educated either (my major subject in university wasn't anything related to computer science). It took me some time to figure out the C# code above üòõ
If you haven't done so yet, please check your other contributions with non-ASCII characters as input and revise the stub generator code and add a similar hint too.

So are my emojis UTF 32?

(If so, I need to edit my constraint section)

I‚Äôve spent some time trying to understand what utf-32 is vs UTF-8 versus UTF 16 ‚Ä¶. but honestly I don‚Äôt get it
I have no idea. Maybe it's better to just list the range of non-ASCII character codes used in this puzzle; that's more precise as well.
Or even, just list the emojis themselves.

I've just tried to use strlen in PHP, and for each emoji it reports a length of 4 (e.g. length of "üçìü•ï" = 8). I wonder if the required length to state in the stub generator should be calculated that way as well.
Have you decided what to do with the "UTF-8" constraint?

I‚Äôm kind of in denial about it honestly. 

I probably should‚Äôve learn more about emojis before doing this puzzle. 

I just learned the basic minimum needed to create and solve it.

It's fine, we all learn from lessons every now and then.

How did you choose the emojis? If there's a particular page which shows all the emojis covered in the cases, then I'd suggest to change the constraint to:

All [[emoji]]s in the cases can be found on [insert link here].

It's a safe way to state the constraint, and at the same time, more precise than the current statement. (Honestly I don't know whether "UTF-8 character set" is a correct description; even if it is, it's still too wide and hence too vague, see here: https://www.fileformat.info/info/charset/UTF-8/list.htm )
